segments.text: This is an interview with Dr. William Alex McIntosh by Melanie Hopkins on November 20, 1988 at Texas A&M University concerning the Vietnam War.
In the interest of accumulating knowledge about this war, I am going to donate this tape to Texas A&M oral history collection in the university archives.
Is that all right with you?
That's fine.
Would you tell me about your place and date of birth?
Okay, I was born in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, November 12, 1943.
Okay, and what is your educational background?
a Ph.D. in sociology that I got at Iowa State in 1975.
And prior to that, I got a master's degree at the same school in sociology.
And prior to that, in the spring of 1967, I got a degree, a bachelor of science in political science from the University of California, Berkeley.
What was your connection with the Vietnam War?
graduated, as I said, in March 67.
I left, actually left school, finished my coursework in December of 1966.
At that time, everybody was being drafted after four years of college, regardless of whether or not they had a degree or not.
And I knew at that time, my student deferment would soon be up.
And I had
prior to finishing school, had looked into the Peace Corps and had found some information on an organization called International Voluntary Services.
I applied to both.
I was very interested in going to someplace in Southeast Asia to work for a couple of reasons.
One, I had taken a lot of courses on Southeast Asia and so wanted to see what it was like firsthand.
And secondly,
sort of felt ambivalent about the war, wanted to serve my country, but at the same time not participate in the war itself.
And so I was hoping to work in Southeast Asia in a peaceful kind of setting, or working in peaceful means.
Peace Corps offered me a couple of possibilities.
One was in Tibet, which is not in Southeast Asia, so I turned that down, and the other was in the Philippines.
It was teaching English, and I didn't want to do that.
And also, the Philippines is a Catholic country, and I wanted to work in a country that was non-Christian just to have some exposure to a different religion.
International Voluntary Services interviewed me in December of 1966, offered me a job early in 1967.
I said yes.
My eagerness to

become a part of this organization was heightened by having a physical exam, being called in for a physical by the military forces, passing that with flying colors and being told that I could expect to be called up within a short period after having passed this physical.
So I worked something out with my draft board.
They basically said that I could
spend two years with International Volunteer Services.
At that time, I thought I was going to Vietnam.
But they say after that two-year period, then they would draft me.
Well, I thought, I'll go to Vietnam, do something positive there.
And maybe in the meantime, something positive will happen with regard to the outcome of the war.
About a month before I was supposed to go,
for training that would start in Washington, end up in the Philippines, and then I would go to Vietnam.
I got a telegram saying that they had too many people going to Vietnam, not enough going to Laos.
And I had a choice.
I could either go to Laos, or I could wait and go to Vietnam in June.
I felt that if I waited, I would be drafted.
And so I said, I'll go to Laos.
Like I said, March was the start of training.

I spent two weeks in Washington every day, kinds of meetings, meeting with former volunteers, members of the State Department, historians, anthropologists, did a little role playing, that kind of thing.
We were then taken to the Philippines, spent approximately a month at the International Rice Research Institute,
in the Philippines, a little town called Los Banos that I don't remember.
We were trained how to grow one of the miracle rice varieties.
Was also given some training in well digging and water seal toilet construction.
And then some, we had a lot of lectures on community development and that sort of thing.
Was then shipped to Laos and spent another
couple of months in language training and again was given some training in well digging, that sort of thing.
We were flown around the country and shown various projects that other volunteers were doing and then after being there a couple of months we were all given our assignments.
I was assigned to a program called a forward area program
And let me take this all back a step or two.
International Voluntary Services had a contract with the U.S. government.
We were contracted by the U.S. Agency for International Development to be basically the field representatives of AID in local communities.
Currently, this was done for a couple of reasons.
One, there had been a big foreign aid scandal back in 1958.
And Laos was part of that scandal, where a lot of money was kind of flowing into the top with no accountability.
And so money for things like extending the airport to make it into a quote unquote international airfield.
You know, the actual bags of cement were stolen.
So the victory monument, a victory monument to show that the Lao had
had defeated the French and thrown off the bonds of colonialism back in 1954.
So this monument could be built, and it was built exactly one meter taller than the French victory monument.
But at any rate, the cement for that came stolen basically from this project.
Well, at any rate, there was a big scandal over this, and there was some debate over whether or not aid should be continued
For this country, on the other hand, there was a civil war going on.

One side was communist, the other side was sort of right-wing to neutralist, and so I guess the Congress decided that it was important to continue to give the right-wing and neutralists foreign aid, but there had to be a lot more strings attached, more controls.
And so what was set up was a kind of, what one of my friends characterized as a parallel government in which from the ambassador all the way down,
to the village level where a lot of the money and materiel was going for projects, there would be an American pair of hens from the top all the way to the bottom.
So the Lao never really had a chance to steal from this program because they never had a hold of it.
There was somebody at the bottom who supervised disbursement of things generally for the
for community development projects.
Okay, back to IVS and my assignment.
I was assigned to a program called Forward Area Program.
The Forward Area Program was an AID brainchild that located always a young, male, American, single, the person had to be single.
They would be placed
in an area that had just been taken out of the hands of the communists.

And the idea was that if you had put somebody into this area, they would be a funnel for rapid supplies of aid, you know, rapid influx of cement, roofing tin, nails, bolts, so on and so forth, so you could build schools, dig wells, build markets, you know, whatever local people wanted

There would be somebody there, and the usual red tape in terms of getting the Lao government to sign all kinds of forms and AID to sign all kinds of forms that other people experienced, all of that was cut to a minimum so that there could be an immediate high impact.
And the idea was to, in essence, demonstrate to people that the Lao government, through help of the American government, was really interested in
and local people.

And so you'd have a bunch of, you know, you'd have people who were being exposed to, you know, this massive amount of aid, you know, after having just lived under the communists so that they would have this contrast.
You know, they would have this mental comparison that they would be making about what it was like, you know, under the communists versus the American-backed royal government.
Apparently not very much because there was not very much for them that the communists had to give.
In fact, the communists apparently mostly redistributed property, drafted people into the army, their army, lived off
You know, they paid peasants, for instance, in script for rice and things that they ate.
But in general, they had very little to give.
They mostly took.
But that was also, to a degree, true of the other side.
The other side kind of preyed on locals, sometimes unofficially, because the Americans supposedly were paying all the bills, and so there was no reason
to extract rice or anything else from local people.
But there were always lots of abuses of that because it was, you know, it's hard to monitor what goes on.
And I saw personally, you know, instances where a local military commander would basically exploit peasants because he had troops that he could use to,
to back up any claims that he might have on somebody's land.
And there was very little that people could do about it.
I got involved in a couple of local disputes in terms of a commander making demands on locals.
And the word filtered through the grapevine back to me that the guy would have me killed if I continued to do it.
So I had the choice of either moving
learning to work within the system, and I felt as though anywhere I went I would run into the same problem, that I would just have to keep my nose out of those sorts of things.
At any rate, the forward area program was sort of blatantly a political kind of thing.
Yeah, it was, in fact, the guy who ran the program was a retired Marine colonel who had spent all of his time
or the majority of his career in the Marines in Southeast Asia, in China.
He was highly experienced.
He had a master's degree in anthropology, but he was very hard-nosed.
And in fact, when I left the country, he had decided that this winning hearts and minds was probably less important.
He basically said, if you grab them by their privates, their hearts and minds will follow, which was a phrase that he had
picked up from, you know, that had been a phrase floating around Vietnam, apparently, for quite some time.
And he had sort of switched his orientation, or at least verbally was changing the way he dealt with people who worked for him.
At any rate, the reason I mention this is because when I joined this organization, one of the things that appealed to me was that it was, because it was a private organization,
it could claim that it was nonpolitical, nonsectarian, so on and so forth.
Well, political in the 1960s had a very specific meaning, or at least it did when a lot of us read that word and volunteered.

It meant, well, you know, this organization is neutral, and so even though we knew we were working for the American government, we, I think, all kind of naively had the impression that we would be able to...
you know, to basically do strictly community development kinds of things.
And, you know, if it made somebody look good, then that was just kind of an afterthought or a lucky byproduct.
But, you know, we were, for the most part, interested in helping people regardless of, you know, who looked good as a consequence.
But the organization was formed in the 1950s
and the non-political and non-sectarian terminology was developed then.
And what many of us came to discover was that non-political simply meant that the organization didn't go after Republicans or Democrats.
They were after young Americans to go do this field work.
It was a very political organization in the first sense that I was talking about because everything that we did had to be approved

by AID and AID was only interested in things that would benefit the local people but at the same time give credit to the Lao government and also not shake any of the social structure or economic structure up in any particular way.
In other words, don't do anything
that as a consequence would make the government look bad or cause people to question economic arrangements.
It was permissible to make people better off economically, but not at somebody else's expense, so on and so forth.
I was kind of offended by all this.
I know there's a lot to talk about, but one of the things I'm going to mention is that when I got there, I was so upset by having felt like I had been hoodwinked
that I started a letter writing campaign.
And I got a bunch of other volunteers who were kind of appalled by this whole thing to write letters as well.
And we, within a year, had gotten this program killed, at least in the sense that they weren't going to send any more IVS volunteers into the forward area program.
And we were
We did it for a couple reasons.
One, because it was highly political, and two, it was very unsafe.
The day I arrived in the country to begin my language training, they brought a body out.
Some kid had been shot in his sleep.
He had been warned, but had decided that he had enough personal contacts in the local area that in essence people would intervene and he wouldn't be
Well, he turned out to be wrong and was apparently shot while he slept in his bed.

And during the time I was there, I lost about six friends because they were, in essence, assassinated because of their connection to the American effort, which was connected to one particular side in this conflict.
And so that was the second reason for trying to kill this program, because it was dangerous as hell.
My first assignment was in a place in the southern part of the country near the Ho Chi Minh Trail.
It was never safe enough for me to go to work there.
In fact, it was never safe enough for me to even visit.
In fact, they kept me in limbo for a while until...
such time that they thought it was going to be safe.
And in the meantime, I got involved in other things.
But I think that was kind of indicative of the kind of program it was.
They put you in very unsafe conditions.
They did give you all kinds of radios and something that was termed a bug-out bag.
We had a bag that had an air-to-ground radio, a portable single-sideband radio that was
connected via an aerial and batteries to radios of a similar type within about 200 to 300 miles.
And with that kind of radius, in most parts of Laos, you could not only raise other people with similar radios inside Laos, but you could even reach people in Thailand.
And so it felt like if you had to leave
in a hurry and go hide in the jungle.
We had all these radios that you can utilize to get yourself out of the dam.
They didn't give us weapons.
And in fact, our organization basically told us, if you are working in a place where you feel like you need to be armed, then you shouldn't be working there.
But that was always kind of a catch-22, because a good deal of the places we worked had the chance over time
not to be unsafe, particularly the longer you were there, the more impact you might have.
And that was eventually going to draw somebody's attention.
So for the most part, the people that I knew that were working in the country stayed unarmed.
I never armed myself.
But one of the guys I worked with had his father send him through the government mail a pistol.
He had a .22 Magnum pistol.
and kept under his pillow.
At any rate, what I did there, well, I was supposed to be in this forward area program.
The place I was initially assigned in the South was never safe enough for me to visit.
I finally convinced people to let me work someplace else, at least temporarily.
They were going to have me sit on my hands, I guess, forever.
And I was young and eager, and I wanted to get started.
I'd been in training for three months.
I had, in essence, a year and nine months left, so I wanted to get started on being a volunteer.
So I found out that there were a couple of guys working in the oldest forward area in the program in the country.
In fact, it was...

old and safe enough so that they were going to change its status and they were going to start moving couples into there and have men and women, married couples, again, Americans for the most part, live and work there and do, you know, kind of a broader range of activities.
You know, more red tape wouldn't take us long, but, you know, it was thought that this particular area had been
you know, receiving high impact long enough, and it was time to kind of slow things down and go through normal channels.
The guys that were working there had a, for the most part, a well digging program going on.

That was about the only thing that they, there had been a lot of schools and that stuff built already, and so about the only thing that was left that local people seemed to be interested in was having wells.
So I volunteered
to go work with the two guys that were working there.
One was a guy from England, and another was a guy from the States somewhere.

And I thought, if I just work with them, at least I get some experience in the field, get to practice my language, and then in the meantime, maybe where I was supposed to go would get safe, or maybe they would reassign me, but at least I wouldn't be sitting on my hands.
So I went out on the field with the Englishman, the American, whose name was Jerry Lewis, of all things,
I was on vacation, so I slept down on Terry's cot.
We were renting the upstairs floor of a wooden building.
A Chinese family owned this building.
They lived on the ground floor.
Their store was on the ground floor.
That's how they made their living.
And then we rented the upstairs.
And the upstairs was a great big...
It was just like a dormitory in some sense.
It was a very big building.
We had a kitchen.
We had kind of a meeting room, living room.
There was one bedroom that the two volunteers slept in.
And then there was a kind of a long dormitory type room in which a couple of Thai engineers and some trainees that worked for them lived.
And those individuals were involved in building dams in that area.
So there was a lot of stuff going on.
At any rate, I was there four days and on the night
On the fourth day, somebody came into our backyard, the path at Leno, and fired a rocket at our open window.
Missed it.
The rocket went through there, pierced the kitchen wall, hit a frying pan apparently hanging on the kitchen wall and exploded, destroying the kitchen, setting the place on fire.
And then some other individuals put about 22 rounds of AK-47 fire
in about floor level, hoping to hit us in our cots.
The bullets came in at an angle, and by the time they were near us, they were already on their way out of the room through the ceiling.
So none of us were hit directly by these bullets.
One of the bullets, however, ricocheted down and hit the Englishman who was sleeping next to me in a cot in the back.
Apparently the bullet had lost a lot of steam by this time, and so what he got was a kind of a long flesh wound down his back.
Another bullet ricocheted and hit one of the Thai engineers in the foot, and then a third bullet ricocheted and hit a kid in the body who was a Chinese child who was living with his family below us.
So there were three people wounded.
We were evacuated at 6 in the morning by basically a military helicopter that had flown from Thailand.
It was an American military helicopter who flew us out.
We were unable to get out any sooner because it was dark, and we also were having trouble.
This was 11 at night when all of this happened.
We were also having trouble with our radio.
Let's see.
And then I did a lot of odd jobs around the country, worked two or three other places.
Two of the other places I worked, I stayed in for, in one place, 14 months, another place about nine months.
Both became so unsafe that I had to eventually leave.
I spent most of my time doing things like, again, digging some wells, building a market,
helped in a rice demonstration program, and then bought rice from local people, that kind of thing.
What experiences did you have with the U.S. government?
Well, I was a direct employee because of our contract.
I was supervised in the field basically by AID,

personnel all the people I work for turn out were former Peace Corps volunteers and so while they weren't necessarily neutral with regard to the war at least they understood what it meant to be a volunteer and they tried to give us as much autonomy as possible but at the same time you know this business of war was always very close at hand because

Again, we were associated with the U.S. government backed side, excuse me, of things, doing programs that were designed to, in essence, shore up the popularity, increase the popularity of the royal Lao government, which was at war with a communist side.
And the communists
Lao forces were supported by Vietnamese communists.
So it was, in many senses, an extinction of the Vietnam War.
There were about 40,000 troops from Vietnam stationed in Laos backing up the path at Lao.
That was the name of the communist group in Laos.
And a good deal of the ferocity of what went on there was due to the fact that the Vietnamese were there to win.
The Lao were always on both sides fairly hang loose.
But the fact that you had Americans pushing one side and the Vietnamese pushing the other tended to make the war probably worse than it would have been had these two sides been
fighting on their own.
In fact, I suspect it would have ended, it went on 25 years before the Vietnamese basically won.
But I think it would have ended a lot sooner had there not been two outside parties, basically.
Sort of like a fight in which two people are fighting one another and at a point they would both like to quit, but there are too many people that are egging them on, so they're unable to quit.
Uh, so I, you know, work on a daily basis, basically, for the American government.
I had to make radio check twice a day to let people know that I was all right.

And if you didn't, if you failed to make radio check, then they would send Air America planes out to search for you, because the assumption was that if you made radio check, something didn't make it, you know, something was wrong.
And if it turned out you didn't make radio check because, uh,
you know, had gotten drunk or just, you know, slept through it, or just, you know, got busy and forgot, then you had to pay for the airtime.
And the little aircraft costs $100 an hour, and the larger ones $200 an hour.
There was somebody who had done exactly this and wound up owing the American government close to $1,000.
which was taken out of his $80 a month for the rest of the time it was there.

The reason that our safety, as it turns out, was such a big deal was because, as we were told by the ambassador, the American ambassador to the country towards the end of my stay there, that they didn't want deaths of young Americans appearing in American newspapers
because people would start saying, well, wait a minute, this kid was killed in Laos.
Don't we have a treaty of neutrality with those people?
What's going on here?
And then somebody would call up their congressman and say, look, what's going on?
A kid from my state or my child was killed in Laos, was shot.
How come?
We're supposed to be, you know, we're not at war there.
We signed this treaty of neutrality.
What's going on?
So we were told, you know, fairly bluntly, we want to keep you alive because we don't want...
anybody raising questions.
And any time one of us was killed, Radio Moscow would announce it as the assassination of a member of the CIA.
Every time one of my friends was killed, that's how their death was publicized by that side.
We got a member of the CIA.

we were, none of us, or at least the people I knew, I wasn't a member of the CIA, and the organization I worked for, IVS, was very careful to try to avoid that kind of infiltration, but there was always some suspicion on our part that because there were some people in IVS who were very ideological and very involved in the war, very interested in it, that there might be some people who were in the employ of the CIA, and we weren't
so worried that they were spying on us.

We just were concerned that they might, in essence, do things that would simply reinforce the image that, well, these are no more than American employees, even though they call themselves members of IBS and they claim to be independent volunteers.
They're just, in effect, the same thing, the CIA, and so it's OK to kill them.

There was a great effort to try to separate ourselves as much as possible from the American government, despite the fact that we were working in an American government program, because we were trying to minimize the jeopardy that people's lives were in.
And again, frankly, a lot of us were there not because of the propaganda value that we posed, but rather just to try to help people.
people regardless of who they're credit for.
Did you have any, do you know of any whatever that was involved in CIA?
Did you ever run into any?

Well, it turns out that the Air America, which was supposedly a private firm, I learned, in fact this was in Newsweek and a lot of news broadcasts and so on and so forth a couple of years after I came back
from Southeast Asia.
It turned out that it was a dummy corporation owned by the CIA.

So in other words, the people that flew us all over the country, we flew around the country because of either there not being any road transportation, and so your only choice was to fly in and out of areas where you work, or because it was too unsafe.
And I flew generally because of a combination of those two.
And so in that regard, we had that kind of connection.
There were a lot of stories that the CIA was working very closely with the embassy, and it was very clear that the embassy was having a lot to say about how the aid program was working.
And so I'm sure that inadvertently we had lots of contact with the CIA.
We just didn't know about it, to kind of give you an illustration of...
you know, how closely tied to the embassy we were.
One time, one person who worked for us, Lau, was killed, shot on the way back to the house we were all living in.
He'd been working in a village, and he had decided to walk with one other guy.
It was about a 10-mile walk, and he got within about four miles of where we lived,
And somebody came out from some bushes, a couple of people, with automatic weapons and shot at he and this other guy.
The other guy was able to escape.
He was hit in the head almost immediately, died instantly.
We took his body back to the Capitol so he could be cremated and so his family, who were from another part of the country, could have a funeral.
And then I flew back in with my immediate aid supervisor to see how he wanted to fly in to make sure everything was okay before he left me there.
And apparently another Lauer who was working for us, who was making radio check while everybody was gone, had reported some kind of fighting nearby.

We frequently reported that, not because we were trying to gather information, but we were basically trying to get somebody to tell us, gee, that body's awfully close to you, maybe you ought to come out of there.
In other words, we frequently reported that kind of thing just to get some kind of check from somebody who knew about military matters as to whether or not we were safe.
And he apparently reported some kind of attack on a village...
And he either garbled it or the person monitoring this call garbled it.
But at any rate, we landed.
We made radio checks saying we got there.
And apparently, as we were making this radio check, there was a squadron of these old World War II aircraft that had been ordered by the American ambassador to do a bombing raid on our

where we were living because somehow this gobble radio message had come out that I was there, the other American that I know was there, we were trapped in our house, we were surrounded by Path at Lowe, and so these guys were going to come in and do a bombing round around our home.
Well, around our home were a lot of civilian houses, and so somebody...
put two and two together and realized, well, if we had just flown in, we could hardly be under attack.

And we had, you know, we called in and said we had just flown in and hadn't said that things were abnormal until somebody realized, hey, we're going to, you know, we're sending somebody to bomb and those guys are okay.
And so they managed to call off this attack.
But in essence, that kind of illustrates how closely tied we were with the American effort.
And since the CIA was highly involved in

What was going on there, and it turns out, incidentally, that AID was used as kind of a cover since it was, you know, AID is a branch of the State Department, but it was being used in Laos as a funnel for military aid.
We had signed a treaty of neutrality in 1962 saying that we wouldn't give aid to any side,
But we were still buying, basically giving the Lao government all of its weapons and even its uniforms.
We were buying uniforms from Hong Kong, and they were being shipped to the country so that the Lao government would have a military that had uniforms.
We were paying for all the food in the military.
We were paying everybody's salary.
It was basically a war that was paid for by us, but we had signed this treaty saying that we weren't supposed to do that, so it all had to
be in some sort of bookkeeping fashion, be accounted for in terms of, I suppose, Rice, Roofington, who knows how they did it.
But at any rate, so it's easy to see, at least from my standpoint, why we were targets, because we were part of this program that was military, that was CIA, so on and so forth.
